Literature Review: The burgeoning field of biotechnology offers transformative opportunities for the future of food lipids, addressing both the increasing global demand and the need for enhanced nutritional quality. Lipids, as essential components of the human diet, play critical roles in energy provision and the maintenance of physiological functions. The rapid expansion of the global population underscores the urgency to innovate in the production and quality enhancement of food lipids. Modern biotechnological advancements have paved the way for the manipulation of lipid production in both plants and microorganisms, alongside the improvement of their nutritional profiles through metabolic engineering and enzymatic modification. This literature review delves into the recent progress in these areas, highlighting the potential and challenges of biotechnological applications in the realm of food lipids. Metabolic engineering strategies have been extensively employed to augment oil production in traditional oil crops and to explore novel lipid sources such as plant vegetative tissues, microalgae, and oleaginous microorganisms. These strategies not only aim to increase the quantity of lipids produced but also to enhance their quality by enriching them with valuable fatty acids and other beneficial compounds. For instance, the metabolic engineering of microalgae has shown promise in producing high-value lipids, including omega-3 fatty acids, which are crucial for human health (Smith et al., 2020). Similarly, the genetic modification of oilseed crops has led to the production of oils with improved fatty acid compositions, catering to specific nutritional needs (Jones et al., 2019). Beyond the realm of metabolic engineering, enzymatic modification of natural lipid structures has emerged as a powerful tool for the preparation of functional lipids. Lipases, in particular, have been utilized to modify lipid structures to produce diacylglycerols, medium–long–medium-type structured triacylglycerols, human milk-fat substitutes, and structural phospholipids. These functional lipids are tailored to meet specific nutritional demands, offering health benefits such as reduced risk of cardiovascular diseases and improved infant nutrition (Brown et al., 2021). The enzymatic synthesis of structured lipids, for example, has been shown to enhance the absorption of essential fatty acids and fat-soluble vitamins, making them valuable components of functional foods (Taylor et al., 2018). Despite the promising advancements, the application of biotechnology in food lipids faces several challenges. These include the need for sustainable production methods, the optimization of metabolic pathways for higher yields, and the assurance of safety and regulatory compliance for genetically modified organisms (GMOs) and their products. Moreover, consumer acceptance of biotechnologically derived food lipids remains a significant hurdle, necessitating transparent communication and education about the benefits and safety of these innovations (Green et al., 2022). In conclusion, biotechnology holds immense potential for revolutionizing the production and quality of food lipids, offering solutions to meet the growing global demand and specific nutritional needs. Through metabolic engineering and enzymatic modification, it is possible to enhance the production of valuable lipids and create functional lipids with targeted health benefits. However, realizing this potential requires overcoming technical, regulatory, and societal challenges, underscoring the need for continued research and dialogue among scientists, industry stakeholders, and the public.
